Title: Type 2 conditional
References: ALEXANDER, L. G.: Longman English Grammar. 20th edition. New York : Longman publishing, 2003. 351 p.
Content:
Second conditional talks about imaginary situations in the if-clause and speculate about their imaginary consequences in the main clause. Though past tenses are used, the reference is not to past time.

   The most commonly used form is: if  +  simple past  +  would

(we can use should, could, might instead of would)

   Imagine: Maybe you will buy a lottery ticket in the future. So you can think about winning in the future, like a dream. It's not very real, but it is possible.

examples:

- If I won the lottery, I would buy a car.

- If the weather was nice, many people would go to the beach.

- If I was taller, I would become a policeman.
